Authors:
Neda Zulge, Arturs Stalazs, Inga Morocko-Bicevska, Sabine
Namniece, Kristine Drevinska, Dmitrijs Konavko
Title:
Gooseberry vein banding associated virus on Ribes in Latvia:
occurrence, host plants and vectors
Keywords:
Alpine currants, aphids, blackcurrants, golden currants,
redcurrants, gooseberry
Abstract:
Ribes (Grossulariaceae) are essential berry crops in the
temperate zones in Eurasia and New Zealand, and viral infections are
common constraints in their cultivation, especially for blackcurrants.
Gooseberry vein banding associated virus (GVBaV) is an aphid vectored
virus that has been reported only from a few European countries and
North America. The knowledge on GVBaV spread and its vectors on Ribes is
still limited. In the present study, we assessed the occurrence of GVBaV
in cultivated and wild Ribes in various habitats focusing on germplasm
collections, wild localities, home gardens and greeneries where chemical
plant protection measures are not applied. GVBaV was assessed in
possible aphid vectors by PCR, and the vectors were identified based on
morphology and partial COI gene sequencing. The genetic diversity of
GVBaV from Ribes and vector species was investigated. GVBaV was
confirmed for the first time in Latvia in all studied Ribes groups,
except Ribes Ã—nidigrolaria, and habitats surveyed; however, its
occurrence did not exceed eight percent. Ribes alpinum and R. aurem were
found as new hosts naturally infected with the virus. GVBaV was
detectable in a single aphid individual by PCR and confirmed in Aphis
schneideri, Aphis grossulariae, Cryptomyzus galeopsidis, Cryptomyzus
ribis, Hyperomyzus lactucae and Nasonovia ribisnigri. Phylogenetic
analyses did not reveal any supported clustering related to host or
origin, except for GVBaV isolates from A. schneideri from cultivated
gooseberry. This is the first study contributing to the understanding of
virus genetic diversity in its vector species in relation to the host
plants. Aphis schneideri that feeds only on Ribes more greatly can
contribute GVBaV spread than other aphid species migrating to the
secondary hosts.
